#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Vianden
#Text=One of Luxembourg 's main tourist attractions , Vianden is a delightful historic town with a stunningly restored medieval castle , spectacularly situated on a rock high above town .
#Text=Think charming cobblestoned streets with typically pastel-coloured Luxembourg mansions and a gorgeous Our valley backdrop .

#Text=Vianden is a traveller 's favourite and although high season will bring in some crowds , it 's a most pleasant little town with a restaurant at every corner and all the fairytale atmosphere you could ask for .
#Text=Coming here , you 'll follow in the footsteps of countless celebrities , famously going back to Victor Hugo , who repeatedly spent time here .
#Text=History
#Text=Vianden 's history goes far back , with a Gallo-Roma castellum preceding the current castle .
#Text=The earliest documented mentions of the town , then called Viennensis , date from the end of the 7th century .
#Text=Building of the castle began in the 11th century and Vianden soon became the seat of the counts of Vianden , but the city gained its charter only in 1308 .
#Text=The town flourished in the Middle Ages , when it was known for its craftsmen , and later on for its leather works .
#Text=The last leather tannery closed in the 1950s .
#Text=The power of the counts of Vianden was at its peak in the 13th century , and so was the grandeur of their castle .
#Text=A Renaissance-style structure was added to the castle in the 17th century , but over time the state of the fort diminished with the stature of its lords .
#Text=As Luxembourg fell under Dutch rule , the town became of little consequence , with earthquakes and a fire further damaging its castle .

#Text=Things worsened when William I of the Netherlands , uninterested in Vianden and its castle , eventually sold the premises to a local merchant , who in turn sold off its interior piecemeal , leaving the place in ruins .
#Text=There were several largely unfruitful attempts at restoration , but it was only in the late 1970s that serious repairs took place and the castle was returned to its former glory .
#Text=For anyone who 's interested in the town 's history , a visit to the castle is a must-do , as it provides a wealth of information on the matter .
#Text=Vianden today
#Text=The revival of the castle immediately turned Vianden into a major tourist destination in the region .
#Text=With its winding roads and rolling hills , the area around town is particularly popular among motorcyclists , who are welcomed by local establishments for the business they bring .
#Text=On sunny summer afternoons the town can get a bit crowded and noisy because of the many motorbikes and visitors , but early risers will find a peaceful village even in high season .
#Text=Tourist Information Office , 1A , rue du Vieux Marché , ☏ +3528342571 .
#Text=The tourist office has information on all the sights in and around Vianden , and it can arrange guided tours and make reservations for hotels or the adventure park .
#Text=It can also provide information on hiking routes starting in Vianden .
#Text=By car or motorcycle
#Text=Most people come here by car or motorcycle .
#Text=It 's a 50 minute drive from Luxembourg city via the N17 , with a scenic final approach .
#Text=Most parking in the village is paid and has a time limit of 3 hours .
#Text=Your best parking options are near the castle , or immediately left before you enter the village .
#Text=Some hotels offer basement private parking for motorcycles .
#Text=Parking spaces are limited , so during the high season in summer , parking could be challenging .
#Text=By bus
#Text=To get here by public transport , e.g. from Luxembourg ( city ) , take a train to Ettelbruck , and then catch the 570 bus at the bus station adjoining the train station .
#Text=It runs twice per hour on weekdays , but less frequently on weekends , and also stops in Diekirch .
#Text=The bus trip takes about 35 minutes , or 20min from Diekirch .
#Text=Vianden is the second to last stop on the route – ask the driver if unsure .
#Text=From Luxembourg city , the entire trip takes about an hour and costs just € 4 for a return ticket including the bus .
#Text=There are also two buses to and from Clervaux in the morning , and another two in the afternoon ( line 663 , takes about half an hour ) .
#Text=In season , a bus from the German city of Bitburg runs to Vianden as well .
#Text=By plane
#Text=The nearest major airport is Luxembourg Findel Airport .
#Text=Alternatively , try Frankfurt-Hahn Airport , which is about 120 km from Vianden .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The town itself is small and just walking down the Rue Grande ( which does have some vehicular traffic ) is a must do .
#Text=The castle is situated on a rock some 300 m above the town centre .
#Text=You can drive a good part up the hill and park there , go up by foot , or walk down from the télésiège stop .
#Text=The télésiège leads from the river side to a restaurant stop even higher than the castle , providing some lovely views over town .
#Text=From there , it 's a 15min downhill walk through the forest to the castle ; the path is fairly rough and steep , so a reasonable level of fitness and appropriate footwear are required .
#Text=The télésiège provides return tickets , but if you want to see the castle in one go , you will need to walk the path back up .
#Text=In that case , buying a single ticket up and strolling down the hill from the castle to town is at least as convenient .

#Text=Alternatively , in summer , there 's a little tourist train that runs through town and up to the castle , offering a convenient way to reach the castle for elderly or less mobile visitors , or another fun activity for kids .
#Text=Its ticket office is near the bridge over the Our .
#Text=See
#Text=The town 's Grand-Rue is as much its functional main street as it is an attraction , with its cobblestoned course and centuries-old buildings on both sides .
#Text=Most buildings remain in use , as hotels , restaurants of residential houses .
#Text=Particularly picturesque is the Place de la Resistance , along the main street , where you 'll find the town hall and a small fountain .
#Text=Vianden Castle , ☏ +352 83-41081 .
#Text=There 's no way to miss the grand castle of Vianden , overlooking and dominating the little town beneath it .
#Text=It was impressively restored in 1977 and has been a real visitor 's magnet ever since .
#Text=A route leads visitors through 20 different historic castle rooms , after passing the modern entrance and soon to be opened visitors centre .
#Text=Some of the rooms ( including the kitchen ) have been fully refurbished , in order to give a real peek into life as it would have been in the castle in the middle ages .
#Text=Others have been restored but leave more to the imagination , including the upper chapel , the impressive Knight 's hall and the beautiful Byzantine Gallery .
#Text=There 's an arms room and a genealogy room , where the family history of the castle masters is explained .
#Text=In short , take your time to wander through these ancient halls .
#Text=It 's a fine trip for adults and children alike .
#Text=€ 6 , student € 4.50 , senior € 5 , child ( 6-12y ) € 2 , children ( <6y ) free .
#Text=Maison Victor Hugo , 37 , rue de la Gare , ☏ +352 26-874088 .
#Text=During his 19 years of exile from France , Victor Hugo stayed in Vianden a few times , most notably for 3 months in 1871 .
#Text=He left behind a painting of the castle ruins as they were at the time and reportedly got the castle architect fired as he thought his work to be insufficient .
#Text=The Maison Victor Hugo is a small museum displaying some original works ( manuscripts and drawings ) as well as the original rooms with furniture as the famous visitor has used it .
#Text=From the museum windows , there 's a lovely view of the castle .
#Text=Audio guides are available in English , French , Dutch and German .
#Text=€ 4 for adults , € 3.50 for young people ( 13-25 ) and € 2.50 for children ( 6-12 ) .
#Text=Trinitarian church and cloister , Grand-Rue , ☏ +352 26-950566 .
#Text=This old church of the Trinitarians is an excellent example of Gothic architecture in the country .
#Text=It was built as early as 1248 , with the large choir originating in 1644 .
#Text=The main Rococo-style altar was created by Michel Weiler in 1758 .
#Text=Adjoining is a small former cloister , from the same 13th century origin .
#Text=Do n't miss a peek in its wonderfully tranquil courtyard .
#Text=The entrance is a simple door on the side of the building , in the alley between hotel Heintz and the church .
#Text=Note the late 13th century effigy of Marie de Spanheim .
#Text=City ramparts .
#Text=In the Middle Ages , Vianden was a fully fortified town , surrounded by city walls with 24 half-round towers and five gates .
#Text=Most of those ramparts are now gone , taken down by Marechal de Bouffiers in 1679 .
#Text=A few restored ruins and a bell tower remain , however .
#Text=Take a quick detour via the small stairway between Grand Rue numbers 58 and 60 .
#Text=It will lead you to the 1603 belfry and some nice views over the village .
#Text=Stadtmuseum ( Musée d’Histoire de la Ville de Vianden ) , 96-98 Grand-Rue , ☏ +352 83-4591 .
#Text=Open Easter to Oct. , daily 11-17 , although in low season it 's closed on Mondays .
#Text=A charmingly small museum , housed in two adjoining buildings on the main street .
#Text=One of the buildings still has its 19th century interiors , while the other serves as a bakery museum , with part of the décor of the 1950s bakery that was housed here on display .
#Text=The house that now has the bakery museum , was once the home of famous poet Edmond de la Fontaine , famous under his pen-name Dicks .
#Text=A tablet on the façade reminds of the buildings famous former inhabitant .
#Text=All the text in the museum is in German , but there 's an English translation text available on request .
#Text=The entrance ticket also gives free access to the copper mine museum in Stolzembourg , about 6 km out of Vianden .
#Text=€ 3 , child € 1.50 .
#Text=Vianden Pumped Storage Plant , ☏ +352 84-90311 . 10:00 - 16:00 , Easter-Sep 10:00 - 20:00 .

#Text=If you have a taste for major industrial sights or large water basins , and would like to get away from the crowds , hike a few kilometres up along the river Our , until you reach the Pumped Storage Plant .
#Text=It has two large reservoirs and was recently expanded .
#Text=The total reservoir capacity is about 10,800,000m³ , making it the largest hydro-electric power plant in Europe .
#Text=It has a visitors ' centre , which allows a peek into its underground power plant . It 's a pleasant walk , along the water , but uphill .
#Text=Free .
